page.title: 08FARMING
page.content: There are nine farms in the area studied and the general pattern of farming is mixed with each individual farm being farmed with a different bias. Two farms were studied in more depth, one of these concentrated more on dairying with the other on sheep and beef. Alwent is a mixed farm of 135 acres, and is worked by the Williams family. Grass is grown for hay and silage and corn for feeding the animals. Mr Williams keeps Masham sheep for meat and wool. The lambs are sold at around 12 weeks old. He mainly has Herefords in his herd of cattle. He keeps bulls and bullocks which are sold as fat cattle at around 18 months old. Warren hens are also kept for their eggs which are sold locally. The hens are productive for two years and are then sold. High Hulam farm comprises 212 acres.
